Two words. Happy Hour. Only two blocks away from my apartment its the perfect place to go to grab some descent grub and some cool drinks at super low prices. Happy hour is from Noon-6:30 and offers discounted prices on Beer, Sangria, Sake Cocktails and Pizza! 

Although the bar doesn't serve any hard liquors, bartenders will mix up tasty and tropical cocktails made from all sorts of Sake. They also offer a ton of beers on tap ranging from Paulaner Hefewiezen to Guinness as well as bottled beer. Wine and Sangria are also served by the glass, and if you had a really hard day pitchers of sangria are there to save the day. 

The food menu is composed of a basic list of appetizers, salads, pizzas and sandwiches. My personal favorites are the Nachos and the Greek Pizza. Don't forget that all pizza's are half-off during happy hour. 

All in all the bar is the perfect place to go to for a low key night during the week with one or two other people to shoot some pool or a wild weekend night full of sake bombs and loud music.
author: Justin S.

description:
I absolutely LOVE this place. The soutwest salad, the nachos, the southwest pizza and best of all they have Abita Amber! The parking can be a challenge if you  have a car but it's so worth it.
The atmosphere is quirky cool and the service is always really nice. Laid back, good prices, one of my favorite places in the Bay Area!
author: Sara G.

description:
I just love this place! I think I would eat here everyday if I could... It's loud and fun and hip. The bartenders are so nice and I enjoy meeting new people so this a cool spot to kind of get that social scene without the creepos trying to talk to you like at some clubs.. the girls and I came after a beauty day and shopping. 4 sake boms and 4 sake martinis each.. seems like a lot, and at first it is but they taste so delicious you just want to keep on drinking!! (you do pay for it later..) 
The food: always good. We had the nachos, like always and the hummus. Just a snack before dinner.. ha  ha! Piggies.. but ya only live once!
author: Jess P.

description:
mmm......Meat.  seriously, that's the name of a pizza as you may already guess what's in it.  I've always passed by this place in a car or bus and wondered if its any good.  Luckily with my band of Happy Hour soulmates, we finally got a chance to check it out!  From people in the east bay to the Marina District, and then the Civic Center, with power combined, we met at Fly Bar around 5:30 where there was plenty of parking around, especially McAllister.    

Happy Hour: 4:30-6:30pm with 1/2 off Pizzas (~$5) and $3 sake/Cocktails/Beer/Sangria

We tried the Mmmm...Meat, Shroom Pie, Funky Chicken, Jimmy Greek, and the pineapple one.  Had to double up on the Mmmm meat and Shroom Pie since it was soo good.   The sizes were good and it was great they sliced it up pretty small.  Each pizza is enough for one person I'd say, but its just so much fun to share and try each one.  

I had the following drinks:
- Sangria - pretty sweet, but not very strong
- Stella 
- Poppy Jasper Amber
- P. Heffenweisner

The total?  less than $20 each, which is really good for a load of food and drinks.  good times.  Good people.
author: Vincent K.

description: Poppy Jasper on tap. Food that is consistently engaging and delicious. The most wonderful personalities in SF behind the bar. Amazing music from the bartender's iPod setting the scene. The rotating art, the view of the hub of the Divis corridor, the camaraderie among the regulars. I live in the neighborhood and proudly call Fly Bar home away from home. Shout out to Russel and Dana for welcoming us early patrons on the weekends.
author: Scott D.

description:
1* for food
1* for the fact that they open till 2am on Sunday
1* for service

This place rocks. Delicious food, pool table, great service. Bartender's really friendly and attentive, not like the kind where he thinks he's cool with the shaking and the straightups. This one carries more smiles. The one thing I wish that they would do is to extend the kitchen hours while the bar is still serving drinks till 2. Well, give kitchen at least till midnight? 

Came here with a bunch of friends (at around 10.30pm). The nice waitress told us that the kitchen will close at 11, giving us only 30 mins to order food. Bummer. So, we have to really scan the menu fast, order everything at once, and everything came at once. We had no idea how much food we ordered, or how little, but there was no way we could order more later anyway.

Nevertheless, food is yummy. pizza is really delicious. I suggest you go for the mushroom pesto. Tuna salad sandwich is good too. Everything's went well pretty much. Would be back.
author: Rika P.

description: Went here on a rainy Saturday afternoon and sat in the cozy front corner of the bar. There's a happy hour 7 days a week so we got $1 off draft beers and a very, very tasty $5 southwester style pizza. YUM! We also tried the baked brie which was absolutely delightful. As the waitress noted, we totally devoured both of the dishes. Service was very prompt and friendly! A great stop.
author: Magda M.

description:
We came here for a drink and dinner. We actually had to wait almost 30 minutes for a table on a Wednesday night, so we sat down at the bar. The bar section was very good - I had an IPA of some sort. They had a pretty decent beer selection on tap.

When we finally sat down, I ordered the grilled cheese. Not quite sure why I ordered the grilled cheese, except that I felt like it. Sometimes you feel like a grilled cheese. This wasn't exactly what I had expected. When I order a grilled cheese. I expect a lot of cheese. This one came with a lot of lettuce (ostensibly a side salad) and not much cheese. The bread was crispy (I like my grilled cheese soft), and it had tomatoes on it. Overall, not bad for a sandwich, but really not my definition of grilled cheese. I would probably order something different next time.

My friend ordered the Cobb Salad with some additions. He seemed pretty happy with his food.

My friends each went to the bathroom during the meal, and were gone for quite some time. I take it that the line was pretty long.

The service was pretty good, and the decor was neat (there are some pictures). I would definitely come back here to drink, although I'm not quite sure about the food. There's a pool table in the back, although I'm not sure if anyone actually plays, or if it's just there for show.
author: Dana L.

description: Cool, easygoing patrons and relaxed ambiance created by warm lighting and eclectic, wall-to-wall murals. My Italian pizzeta was pretty good, but I guess I should have gone during happy hour, because the bartender overcharged me. I pointed this out to which he replied "it's rounded up." Is this something restaurants and bars normally do in this city? I felt embarrassed squabbling over pennies but also pissed that they'd taken liberties in charging my credit card. 10 pennies times 1000 patrons equals $100. There's plenty of cool, hip places in SF, so I don't plan on frequenting this place again. They get 2 stars as opposed to 1 star, because I want others to take my review seriously in case they have a similar experience.
author: Danielle S.

description:
Sangria? Delish. That's probably the main reason I go back here. That and the low key, sexy red walled, dimly lit New Orleans-ish loungey vibe that I enjoy so much. 

Also, it's a rare place where you can somehow get away with either wearing a ratty t-shirt/shorts or being dressed up for a night out on the town--love the "come as you are" vibe.

Although there's another outpost in Nob Hill, I like this one 10 times better.
author: Britt M.

description:
Fly bar is supa-fly baby, oh yeah.

Let's start with what a jacked-up week I had.... the arrival of Friday night was way overdue. natalie came rushing over to my house, she wanted to go out and play. She also had plans for us. I love plans!

We shared a little tequila, had a vent session about our week and then headed out praying for good cab karma.... It was nearing 10pm and prime cab-fighting hour. We braced ourselves for war. Nope, we got one right away and sped off into the night to Fly bar. I had never been to this bar before, so carefully I started crafting my yelp review on the way over. Haha  sadly not kidding about this.

We walked in and it all just hits you at once...  the stunning colorful murals, the soft lighting and the great crowd. Like a trifecta of visual euphoria. it was insanely crowded but we maneuvered through to find natalies friends waiting for us with beer. Hmm.... 5 ridiculously good looking guys waiting for us with beer? Oh my pretty friend Natalie, this is why I love thee so.

Our group had a great time here.... The only negatives were: trying to order a drink up at the bar was like trying to locate a living, breathing republican in san francisco. Next to impossible. Or that this completely drunk 6 foot amazon chick towering behind me kept elbowing me in the back the entire time with her giantess monster pointy elbows.  

Finally one of the guys in our group insisted we head over to O'keeffes next...  I was not going to argue about this, because as much as I loved fly bar, the crowd was getting a little sweaty and crazy. 

Final thoughts are, i will surely come back.... but maybe on a week night instead, when the cool kids come out to play, because Fly is definitely supa-fly in my book. 

*insert sizzling sound here*
author: Michelle I.

description:
What's not to like? 

People who complain about soju cocktails know little about the industry, or really the city, because Type 48 licenses are hard to come by and there are reasons why they're fewer and farther between in certain neighborhoods but if anyone besides me cared about the historical underpinnings of human phenomena, I'd have more friends and we damn sure wouldn't be in Iraq. Fuck this world. Let's go have a (soju) cocktail. 

I like Fly. I loved it as a USF student, because back in the day before the massive ABC crackdown on selling to minors (punish the kid with the fake ID, not the bar!!!) Fly was the spot for a midday snack, a refreshing sangria and a friendly game of pool. And the value of the midday snack goes underappreciated. A wise woman once said, "why can't you get a sit-down meal between 3pm and 5pm anywhere?" Indeed. Well, at Fly, which used to be a pizza place so there's a bonus kitchen in the bar, you can get a variety of tasty snacks at many off-peak times, usually served by a no-nonsense tattooed hottie of either gender. That's big value, in any neighborhood. 

You want to look down upon Fly because you're a 94117 culture whore (or an ignorant slut who just "discovered" this amazing neighborhood called "NOPA"), but the reality is, if you stumbled upon a place like this in a less sophisticated neighborhood (and if you were here back then, you know that this used to be a much less sophisticated neighborhood) you would be stoked.
author: Megan W.

description:
I try to be careful with my 5 star ratings. 

And for this place I have to give 5 stars for the following reason: it is the perfect little dark neighborhood bar/restaurant/meeting place. 

It's dark with funky artwork. It's cozy, and not too big. They serve basic foods that can quench your hunger and not interfere with your drinking. They serve lots of good and reasonably priced drinks. The service is good, and consistent. It is never ever overly packed. 

The only thing that really would ever even take away from the 5 stars here is the fact that parking here sucks. But of course if you live in the neighborhood, then you probably wouldn't have to worry about parking you'd be walking.
author: Denise B.

description:
Fly Bar is the fucking best. My previous hateration was unwarranted and while I still hate soju, I make do with their excellent sangria or a yummy beer, of which they have a fine selection, including Belgian favorites Duvel and Chimay (I go big or go home). 

The best thing about Fly though, is that you can have a tasty, inexpensive, wonderful meal in a setting that is not your janky, usual SF chalkboard menu cafe and is not quite the production a meal at Little Star or Tsunami is. It is dark and sexy and attractive and the kind of place I want to eat dinner at every night.  Lunch is great here, too - you can watch all the activity of Divisadero street from their big windows and listen to all the neighborhood gossip from the crew of older men that hang out here to watch baseball and read the paper.  
 
(Of course, the weekends and late evenings here are annoying, but wtf else is new?) 

Anyway, Fly. You can find me here all the time. I'm the one on the sidekick, grinning like a fool and drinking gallons of sangria.
author: Maria D.

description:
A little too hipster for my blood, Fly is the place for people who clearly put a lot of time and effort into looking like they didn't put in a lot of time and effort. 

Fly is for you if:
You wear skinny jeans
You like pointy-toed flat shoes
You have money but dress like trailer trash
You have a retro-mullet
You like to scowl for no reason
You live in NOPA and actually call it NOPA

My companion and I spent most of the time making out at the bar, so it was easy to ignore the lack of true atmosphere. Plus, it's kind of our hood, so we're pretty comfortable regardless of our khaki pants and black sweaters.  I used to like Fly a lot better. I'm not really sure when the place took this turn for the different but I'll probably just hit up Bar 821 from now on, as was initially suggested by my partner in crime. My bad. I won't make the same mistake again. Warning: do not drink the sangria unless you want to be carried home. This stuff is high-octane and is apparently of the time-release variety. It hit me for HOURS after I finished one glass.
author: Autumn K.

description:
I've been coming to the Fly Bar for years but haven't been in a little while prior to happy hour last night...I'm pleased to report that things are as good as ever.  Great happy hour deals (half priced pizzas and $3 sangria/draft beer/sake) make Fly Bar the perfect spot for a bite and a pint before a show (or in our case a movie) at the Independent.
Special thanks to our waitress for giving us happy hour prices on a round of drinks even though it was after 6:30pm.  I like nice people.
author: phil h.

description:
Where did these people come from? Have they been hiding out in the neighborhood all along, or did someone say "Hey guys, lets go halfway across town to drink at a beer & wine only place even though there are tons of full-service bars in our neighborhood" at some point? They're not elbowing me or screaming in my ear so it's fine. (It's early on a weeknight; They might do this stuff at other times.)

But Fly is nicely decorated except for a picture of some goofy looking kid hanging over the bar, and there's a good selection of bottled beer. Only a few things on tap though, and the wine selection isn't huge. My companion says the sangria is potent. And she's no stranger to strong drink.

After a while, if you go across the street and run into AKA G at the entrance to Bar 821 and you mention to him that you just came from Fly, he'll just look at you and shake his head and you'll just want to sink into the pavement right there. you need to be ready for that.
author: matthew r.

description:
I had my 'leaving San Francisco' party here at the weekend. 
We arrived at about 8.30 , and there were tables and everything ! 

This is an awesome place to start a big night as it has everything.. pool table, lots of tables, awesome bar peeps, cooooool cheezy music. 

The guys who I was with promised to all strip if I got the bar guys to put Journey on .. they copped out as it was the wrong song ( losers !) but I was dead chuffed that the bar peeps were up for trying .. they also gave me a free sake/ cider drink thing that I had to down .. Yum! 

Ive been here a few times and the only reason it doesn't get 5 stars is it only has 1 restroom .. not good when it gets busy! 

Thank you Fly Bar for making my leaving night so wonderful and for getting me well on the way to toastedness! waka waka
author: Amy W.

description:
This place is too small for your big ego, so if you've got one - leave it at the door or go elsewhere.  

I love Fly because it's just a cool spot full of really down to earth, friendly locals. It's a mix bag crowd from different social groups and generations and I like it that way. Laid back, chill and mellow. The wait staff is awesome  and they go out of their way to take care of us.

We practically live off the 1/2 price happy pizza special (Book'em Dano...yum!!) and I love their homemade sangria.

Bring in your favorite vinyl on Tuesday afternoons for turntable tuesdays.
author: Melissa J.

description:
My brain: QUICK ORDER A DRINK IM STARTING TO SOBER UP
Me (to brain): No you aren't.
My brain: MORE DRINKS ANYWAY
Me: Hmm...mangorita...
McV: That sounds good?
My brain: BUT I DONT LIKE MANGOS
Me: I don't think I like mangos?
McV: Really?
Me: I have issues with things in the melon family, like pineapples. 
My brain: NEITHER OF THOSE ARE MELONS YOU SHITWAGON
Me (to brain): Shut up and pick a drink!
My brain: NO YOU PICK A DRINK
Me: They are all Soju cocktails anyway. I guess this bar doesn't have a liquor license. I'll probably get a beer.
McV: Yup.
Bartender: What'll it be?
Me: Uhh...uhhh...
Me (to brain): Help! Drink! Say something!
My brain: MANGORITA
Me: Mangorita!
McV: Make it two.
Me (to brain): Oh goddammit you suck.
My brain: HAHA 
McV: I thought you didn't like mangos OR Soju cocktails?
Me: I fucked up.
My brain: HAHA
Bartender: Two mangoritas.
McV: Okay, these are really nasty.
Me: Yeah, I figured.

I didn't end up trying anything else besides the mangorita, so maybe the rest of their drink selection is better. The scene seemed reasonably chill -- crowded but not packed -- so although I wasn't super-impressed on Friday I'd give it another go in the future when my brain is in a less mischievious mood.
author: Liz G.

description:
Do you remember before Fly this little corner had the world's dirtiest, nastiest, emptiest pizza joint in the city?  (Taking you back to pre-gentrification when it was still the Western Addition.)  Well, five stars just for taking rotten lemons and making some darn good hard lemonade.

Here's a neighborhood bar with cute cheap decor and cute cheap drinks to match.  I love the budget gourmet bar food (course I loved it more when they served weekend brunch, but that was a LONG time ago) and recommend the pizzas if you're feeling skinny and the salads if you aren't.

http://www.cleanscores.com/1547
author: Ann W.

description:
Oh Fly Bar, you're why I miss SF.

This was my go-to happy hour spot, and I swear I was in there at least once a week. A-MAZING. The cocktails are quite good (warning: like a lot of places on Divis, they don't serve hard liquor, so these are sake cocktails -- not bad, but don't expect a martini), but I always end up going back to the sangria. The only food I've had are the pizzas, which are varied and pretty damn good, especially when you're paying half price, and easily large enough to split or save.

Service can be a little slow, and there's just the one bathroom, so this is definitely better for after-work happy hour than full-blown night out (I've done both, and earlier is definitely better) but otherwise, I can't imagine a better place to eat, drink and be merry. 

Fly Bar, I heart you!
author: Kate Z.

description:
This place has a brand-new purpose in my life. It has officially become my pre-Independent go-to place for sangria and grub prior to shows. 

The art is gorgeous, the lighting is soft and makes us look pretty, and it always seems rammed, but doable. I've never had a hard time getting a seat. 

Their warm spinach salad is awesome and it has bacon in it! Best idea ever. Reminds me of my mom's wilted lettuce salad from childhood. Yum AND nostalgic!

And it's spitting distance from the Independent, so you can do some cheapesque drinks there prior to coughing up the big coin for tiny cocktails at Independent. 

Do it. You know you want to.
author: Rachel F.

description:
I can't believe I haven't written a review of Fly yet.  I live really close so I'm probably here more than I'm at any other bar.  The drinks are good in general, but the best deal here is the happy hour special.  From 3:30-6:30 daily, drinks are $3 and pizzas are all half off.  Today I got four people faded and ate a pizza for $25.  That's pretty fly.  

Also, it was here that I learned that I get much better at pool the more sangria I consume.  Here is how you can tell:

0-1 drinks - Balls will be flying off the table.  You will see my friends on the floor.  They are down there because they are laughing at me.  Laughing so hard they can't stand up.  
1-2 drinks - Friends are upright.  Balls are on the table, but may not necessarily be going into holes. 
2-3 drinks - I become focused.  Friends aren't laughing.  Balls start going into holes.
3-4 drinks - I'm the zen master of the pool table.  Balls are whizzing into holes all over the place.  I start hitting crazy shots that require complex geometry I never took in school.  
4+ drinks - I'm on floor, passed out.  But in my drunken dreams I'm still really f'ing awesome at pool.
author: Katie S.

description:
When you just want a drink and a dark, cozy and friendly bar to discuss the more serious aspects of life...like...."What beer do I drink next, Chimay?"

There is no better place to go than Fly Bar.  A laid back super chill bar with a great selection on tap.  

Either with just a friend or a whole group of tired, drunk and happy friends after a long day of work...it's a great place to either start a night or end one.
author: Jay H.

description:
The Fly is one of those places that I wouldn't normally rush to if I didn't live in the neighborhood.  The decor has always been a bit strange for me and most recently got even stranger. I know they tried to fancy it up by removing the chalk board and stuff, but now with all the crazy shaped mirrors and bright concrete bar I kinda feel like I should light some incense and wear my sarong. Besides that though, I do like the crowd that comes into the Fly. The bartenders are also very, very nice people and pretty attentive when you need a refill--even when it's crowded. The Fly also has a great happy hour deal on their pizzas at four bucks a pop until 6:30. I can't tell you how many times this has saved me when I've been dirt poor or trying to entertain out of town friends on a budget. 

I often find myself wandering into the Fly as my last stop of the evening, which can sometimes be absolutely dangerous! Just a week ago, after a night of bar hopping to 4 different bars all over the city, my friend texted me to meet him there for a drink. I was already buzzed so I was only planning on having one and going home but noooooo, that did not happen. After the bar closed, I had the bright idea of running to the liquor store, getting some tall boys and drinking them in alamo square park until the butt crack of dawn. And the next morning???? Or should I say afternoon, I felt like death was coming to get me. But that's why I love the Fly. at my old age, it's rare I do that kind of thing anymore, but that sangria has something in it to keep me going!
author: Jade L.

description: Hands down my favorite happy hour place in the city. My coworkers and I come here pretty regularly. Great happy hour specials (1/2 price pizzas)! Love the pitchers of sangria, the shroom & meat lovers pizzas, the nachos, & the salads. They also have a good hummus plate. There's a pool table in back, sports on the TV, and good music.
author: Jenna R.

description: I went to Fly bar last night with my friends. The exterior doesn't look very impressive but the interior is really nice. there were plenty of tables and sitting area. I loved the dim and red walls. The crowd and atmosphere is very causal and laid back even though there is a bouncer in the front of the bar.  if you are here are to get a drink, you wont find the typical alcohol drinks. Fly bar only serve Sou & Sake cocktails & draft beers. $4 for 19oz draft beers and around $5 for sake of soju cocktails. Surprisingly the soju cocktails serve in martini glasses are really good. I ordered a Sou Pear Soy milk drink (VERY YUMMY and LIGHT). the bartenders are super nice and very attentive. i will definitely go back to the Fly bar to just chill and mingle with my friends.
author: Carol Y.

description:
Fly Bar is a nice cozy standard bar. $4 beer on draft, good eats and a nice staff, plus a lot of seating (though it does fill up). 

It's next to a lot of restaurants, which makes it a great spot to have a drink while waiting for dinner.
author: Sara W.

description:
Nice art, fab happy hour, good music, tasty cheap eats + drinks. 

I have never been in this place past 7 p.m. but between 3ish and 6ish, this is an ideal spot for afternoon drinking and snacking.
author: Whit P.

description:
Do yourself a favor and order their pizza.  It's really really really good.

The place has a nice dark atmosphere, and the people who work here are nice.  It can be kind of crowded and annoying on Wednesday nights for some reason, but if you go on the weekend, the crowd about fits the time of night.
author: John S.

description:
+ nice decor, free pool nights, sake cocktails, sangria, good tunes, wide array of beers, better than most bar food 

- only one bartender on most nights, one unisex bathroom, no hard liquor, limited parking, cops frequent the coffee shop across the street (so if you plan on driving home after a few drinks, don't stumble as you walk to your car)
author: rachface -.

description:
I was very impressed with Fly Bar's Sake Cocktails. The mixed fruit drinks, like the Sake Suckle (pear) and the Sake Breeze (pineapple and cranberry), were very light and refreshing, with a hint of sake.  Although, these drinks seem lightweight, they actually do pack a punch.

The atmosphere at Fly Bar is quaint, yet pleasant.  The wall behind the bar is filled with mirrors of all shapes and sizes. Quirky paintings decorate the rest of the bar and you can play pool at the table in the back.

I also really enjoyed the music being played while I was there. They had hip-hop from 90's - present and some 80's pop.

I will definitely try out happy hour here again. Bar Fly's happy hour is daily from 3:30pm - 6:30pm. They offer deals on beer, sangria, sake cocktails, and pizzas (half off).
author: Sam T.

description:
I'm a vodka girl. I'm also a wine girl, a sake girl, a soju girl and a beer girl once in a blue moon. With that said, when I order a martini, I generally prefer them to be of the vodka variety and so the whole soju martini thing is still a bit odd to my taste buds. They are good, don't get me wrong, but nothing beats that crisp yumminess that is a vodka martini and if you are looking for that, don't come here.

As the other reviews explain, this is a beer and soju bar for the most part. I didn't realize that when i walked in with a group of friends and was handed what looked like a Cosmo. It was a pink ginger something or other and while good, it just wasn't what I was expecting or wanting.

Besides all of that though, this place is great! It's totally cute inside and still has a bit of a divey feel, but kicked up a few notches. The lighting is neat, the art is neat, the people are neat and whether you are here at night or in the afternoon, it's a great space to hang with friends and enjoy a good time. 

I've been here a few times now on my trips up to SF and I am definitely a fan...that is when I am in a beer or soju mood, otherwise, I am heading down to Nopa and drinking some vodka :)
author: Stephy S.

description:
It's a rare bar that gets a five-star rating in my book, as this 'particular' patron can usually find something wrong with just about any establishment. Annoying patrons, crappy beer/wine list, bad neighborhood, ugly bartender...you name it. Yet Fly has surpassed even this critic's sharpest eye and come out on top. Bravo, Fly, you've topped my list. 'Why?' you ask?

For one, they serve Poppy Jasper. For those of you not in the know, this is hands down the tastiest microbrew around, yet can only be found at a few establishments (Zeitgeist for one) in town. This was the original reason I kept coming back time and again...that, and the fact it's two blocks from my house. But I digress. Poppy Jasper accounts for at least ONE of these stars.

Then there's the menu. I've yet to order anything I don't like (and at this point, I've pretty much made it through the whole menu). The Black Forest Ham and Brie sandwich is a delight, as are these "salads on top of pizzas" whatever-they-call-'ems. YUM. That's star TWO.

Decor adds the third star; I believe this is owned by the same people that own Solstice and Brick, yet any and all possible pretension is removed leaving behind a cozy, neighborhood feel. The series of paintings hung high on the wall are unique and eye-catching, and the hanging paper lanterns over the pool table (always in use, but somehow unobtrusive) create a warm, inviting light to the venue. 

At this point you'd start looking for flaws and might turn to the service to find one, except this is NOT the case. The bartenders are prompt, attentive and friendly despite usually being slammed, and the servers demonstrate the same attention to their customers. Even on nights when there's a waiting list for seating, they are patient and kind and when you DO get seated, will make sure that you always have a full beer and aren't lacking for grub. The fourth star is well-deserved for this.

As for star five, I'll admit it: it's the location. One block down from The Independent (and two from my house), it's many a night when I walk in and see friends among the many patrons at Fly. In fact, it's become our local watering hole, mainly for the reasons listed above but also for that genuine feel of camaraderie and the fact that, after a long night and a full tummy, we can stumble home easily without incident. While "Cheers" is a fictional concept, it's not too far off from the affection that I feel for this locale. Everybody may not know my name, but the staff sure knows my face...I come here weekly, for good reason.
author: Aubrey S.

description:
This place is in something of an unsavory neighborhood, but that's OK because, like me, most of the people in the joint seemed to be just passing through. Good - it looks crowded, but the tables turn over fairly quickly.

I found the people, both staff and clientele, helpful and friendly - not snooty or overly-hip as others have said, although one guy did drop the "NOPA" moniker a couple of times.

You could use say this place is "confused" or "lacking direction" - or you could be kind and say "eclectic". The music was "eclectic", 80's and 90's dance mostly. The drinks were "eclectic" too - with good beer and a variety of sake-based cocktails and a tasty-enough, so-called-but-not-really "sangria". The decor is eclectic - dark and "moody" for the most part, with accents of pop-art and some paper-lantern stars I liked, hanging in the back - certainly plenty of "atmosphere".

I would come here again, but I can't see myself spending the whole evening. Certainly a great place to meet up before heading off to an evening of "fun" in "NOPA".
author: Kingpin X.

description: They have an awesome Happy Hour.  It is a dollar off of all draft beer!  So a glass of Downtown Brown Ale was only $3.  My friend and I ordered 2 draft beers and a pizza.  The bill came out to only $12.50.  What a steal!  This is definitely a spot to check out for happy hour.  Expect to see me roll by the place more.
author: Shad B.

description:
I thought this place would have 115 reviews! I finally stopped in after living in the neighborhood for a few years, and was pleasantly surprised--sexy-dark interior and good service (I'm so sick of wine-beer-soju joints I could spit, but I know there's a limit on liquor licenses in SF, so I order my wine and shut up). 

We would have stayed longer if Loner Guy we saw leering at Bar 821 hadn't followed us over and slimily slunk in the stool behind me, nearly inciting the bfriend to violence.

We'll go back for some grub and wine, but they can keep their soju cocktails (and their ogling goon).
author: Gretchen T.

description:
Ehhh.....

It's my neighborhood bar and they always seem happy to see me (of course that happens EVERYWHERE I go), but I'm with Maria D. SOJU...bitch please indeed. It's like drinking children's wine. Which I developed a tolerance to at age FIVE.
author: Suzanne R.

description:
This spot brings me back, Bill and Ted's style, to the hazy mid-90s .com boom.  Oh, the memories!  Long afternoons, sipping into the night...oh, Fly Bar, how I loved thee!

Flash forward to 2009.  I was meeting a cute gentleman pal for drinks. Fly Bar?, he suggested.  Flashbacks of boy bands and millionaires on paper came flooding back.  Sure, why not?

Scooting in to the Divisadero haunt was like stepping back into time.  The crowd, with exception of my friend (who had as his hot boy prop Hemingway's A Moveable Feast) looked like they had fallen from a Squirrel Nut Zippers  or Geggy Tah video-  lots of baggy cargo pants and horn rimmed glasses. The music was "Mexican Radio" by Wall of Voodoo.  There was something unpretentious and comforting, however, especially compared to the 'scene' that usually comes with many outings in the city.

My one pal ordered a Stella.  I got super girly, and went for a sake, soy milk and pineapple juice concoction.  Drinks were between $4-$6 each-  not to bad for this recessionista.
author: Jennifer O.

description:
I lived really close to Fly bar for quite a bit of time... but never really hung out here a ton. It's got much more of a cafe vibe than a bar with all of the tables. It's also really small so if you don't get a table or bar stool you really don't have anywhere to stand that's not awkward.

However; they do have a great happy hour with $4 beers and $5 pizzas!
author: Thel D.

description:
I think under different circumstances I would have liked Fly Bar a lot better, because honestly, I went there under what for me constitutes bad circumstances: I was extremely hungry.  In case you didn't know, I am the hungriest person on the planet.  

Anyhow, we got there for some post happy hour chow and my excitement over getting some hot food in my belly evolved after about half an hour to rabid hungry table gripping.  And then another 30+ minutes passed and I was ready to gnaw my arm off.  We finally got our food after over an hour of waiting, and while my pizza was decent, I could have already digested some delicious fried chicken from nearby Popeye's by that time.  Oh, and the place, while busy, was not by any means packed.

So, definitely worth another try for drinks and snacks, just don't come hungry.
author: Tanya N.

description:
This is to Susie. 

Who has the prettiest knees for wearing swirly dresses like she usually does. 
My highschool bosom-friend and when she'd asked, "Do you want boys bad enough?"
I answered, "Yeah, ok."
Then Susie pursed her lips and said, "Like this." What I remember now as her trying to be as an adult when she made her face stern, shoulders square. Then she said, "Lemme show you how to wear eyeliner."

There in the bathroom during homeroom, I learned an inch. An inch of womanhood. Just a part of what I would continue to discover. 

Happy birthday, Susie.
author: Jenny T.

description:
Where can you find the best sangria in town?  Well, the Fly Bar of course. Your taste buds will thank you for bathing them in such delight and if you go during their happy hour your wallet will thank you as well.

Now that I've got that out of my system. This is a cool bar. When I visited there seem to be a lot of locals watching the game and having a beer. I'm told it gets livelier on the weekends. Also go and check out the art work on the wall....mmmM very interesting stuff.
author: Stacy F.

description:
Decent enough place.  It gets a little crowded ,and more so when there is something big going on at the Independent.  

They only serve beer, wine, and sake drinks.  What is the purpose of a sake drink again?

I will say that I've always been treated well by the folks behind the bar, which goes a long way with me.
author: Nelson W.

description:
NACHOS.  Wonderful tortilla chips, layered with cheese, stacked again with more chips, and continuing into a pattern that leads to the sky.  A mountain of nachos!  Can you imagine...?

Then, they bake the nachos, and lather on the sour cream and guacamole... LOTS OF IT.  And then... and then?!??!  

You eat it!!  Yeah!!!
author: Michelle N.

description:
I went here one night with a few friends who said it was a great little bar. 

And while I enjoyed the artwork, the enormous menu over the bar listing all the hip/trendy martini and sangria drinks was a little overwhelming. Just give me a drink damn it! Don't make me choose from a list of 500 concoctions.

So here's why this place gets 2 stars. Scenario: Friend and I go up to the bar and start discussing the menu where we have 500 choices:

Me: What are you getting?
Friend: I have no idea. You?
Me: I don't know. I'll ask the bartender what his favorite is. If I can get his attention. Bartender? Oh Bartender?

(5 minutes later)

Me: Do you know what you're getting?
Friend: I was thinking about the Ginger Cranberry Pineapple Grape Strawberry-infused Cherry Sangria. You?
Me: I dunno, I was thinking about the Melon Mango Banana Watermelon Cranberry Martini.

(Still waiting for bartender to actually pay attention to customer)

(5 minutes later)

Me: Bartender? Oh Bartender?

(5 minutes later)

Me: EXCUSE ME!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

So finally he came up and took our order. I didn't even bother asking him what he recommended because he seemed to involved in trying to act cool to even listen. 

Yeah I'll probably go back some time. I guess one time being to a place can't really do it justice... And besides, the drink actually was pretty good. And I've got 499 more to try.
author: Chantal H.

description: This is definitely a bar with upscale bar food rather than a restaurant with a bar as an ancillary use.  So take note if you had planned to try this out for a nice dinner.  That said, I do like all the saki martinis they have here, in lieu of hard liquor, which they apparently do not have license for.  Though I wouldn't describe it as trendy, its a pretty hip and edgy joint with decent food, cheap drinks, and lots of USF trixies.  However, the eye candy tends to have quite the attitude, it gets super crowded and is very dimly lit.
author: Rick H.

description:
great $3 sake cocktails for happy hour and the food is awesome. The ones with sangria are the best!!

It gets pretty packed on the weekends, but the crowd is always cool. And the music is usually full of surprises.
author: Kandace K.

description:
SO.... This is by far my favorite place in the city. I've recently moved to San Diego, and have relied heavily on yelp, so I thought I'd return the favor. Back to Fly Bar...

Location:
Good... I mean what else is there to say? Easy to get to, lots of bars and food around... so yea, location is good.

Drinks:
While they don't have a full bar, the drinks are still yummy! I recommend the Mangorita or the Nigori Punch. Also, the Sake Bombs are the best!!! They make them with cider so they taste like candy (very good, but very dangerous)!

Food:
Excellent! It's a BAR... but Fly has a great menu, and they serve late! My picks are the Humus and Tapenade Plate, or the Goat Cheese Chicken Quesadilla.

Clientele:
Chill, it's pretty mellow in there during the week. It's pretty much locals. What's great about this is the staff gets to know you =) On the weekends it can get a little more crazy, but if you get there before 9pm you can usually get a table.

So, all in all, this is a great place that I highly recommend!
author: Daryah N.

description: This review is much overdue.... I have been coming to Fly for a couple of years now and every time, is a damn good time especially 90's hip hop dance night on Saturday night. Hands down, my favorite night of the week. Timmy the DJ is awesome. He's always playing the baddest jams of my favorite decade. No there isn't really a dance floor, but I do my best to push away the tables and chairs and take it over, beat up the beat, bust a groove, shake my a$$, break it down, and whatever else you'd like to call it. The best part is anticipating what the next song is gonna be and you are like "Oh snap, I remember this from 1993!". I LOVE IT and can't help but have a fantastic time with my peeps, all while sipping sangria and spilling it all over myself.  All the bartenders rock too. So make your way on over. You may see me there. I will be the tall, uncoordinated white girl breaking it down!
author: Theresa A.

description:
I was visiting San Francisco and on a tour bus with a group of seniors visiting USF deciding if we would go to school there or not. Our bus cruised down Divisadero and one of the student tour guides from USF informs us that to our right was Fly Bar and when we were older we would go there and spend a lot of time. She proved to be right. We loved getting dizzy off sangria and flirting with the boys that visited. It was a stop after (and before) shows at the Independent. Just a great neighborhood hangout!

I came by recently for a bit of nostalgia. Harkening back to the days when I was still escaping midterms or drowning in final papers. The faces were still familiar. Our server was a bit batty ... just as I had left her. I must admit until my most recent visit I had no idea there was food here. But the half price pizza happy hour is great. A good place to chow down on a rustic California pie.

I really like places where you don't have to put on a front. There's no agenda at Fly Bar. Be who you are and come in for a beer. You'll be glad you did.
author: Lauren S.

description:
I'm hesitant giving Fly four full stars, but the nachos and salads came in bowls large enough to wash a chihuahua in.  The food at this bar is surprisingly good with the selections of pizza and pizzettas (pizzas with a tasty salad on top)... especially the Thai Chicken Pizzetta. 

There are a number of beers on tap, bottles of wine, as well as a large soju selection. Good high ceilings that glow with local art. Sure, it can get crowded and service can suck at times, but this bar is worth taking a look for a drink and a bite to eat.
author: I Love Beef C.

description:
Came here after a mediocre Holloween house party. I was looking for more booze so we headed over here. Not quite as posh as say the marina but whatever. You could tell nobody here grew up on welfare and had a car in high school. They have a pool table all the way in the back and some nice big booths that remind me of bottle service tables at night clubs. 

They only serve beer and wine variants here, like soujou and sake. They make up for it in really good prices. 4 bucks for really good beer on tap like sierra nevada and stella and 5 bucks for signature drinks. Lots of traffic outside too so its easy to get a cab if you need it. Nice place to chill with friends for a few drinks. This was the first non ghetto place that played E40... I wanna be saaaaaved.
author: chris c.

description:
We moved around the corner about a year ago and really wanted to make this our neighborhood go to.  However, while there are some people I see there regularly, there are lots of annoying hipsters.  They don't have a deep fryer, so there are no fries.  The female bartender is awesome and always remembers me and my husband since we (used to) frequent it often.  The main male bartender, who I think is the manager never has much to offer as far as conversation or bar tenderly attention.  The last time I went, he actually put the beer of the guy who was sitting next to me on my tab.  The food can take up to 45 minutes to come out.  We tried to order ahead and then go to the bar since we live a a block away but the above mentioned bartender told us, "that it wouldn't "honor" the customer's that were already there."  So we will honor this location with our regular dollars.  

So if you are visiting the neighborhood, enjoy cheap beer and food, as long as you have the time to spare to wait it's a mediocre location.  As for us, the locals, we'll be heading to the other local spots in the future.
author: Aurora H.

description:
Ok, so they don't serve hard liquor.  Minus a star for that.  Otherwise it's a pretty legit bar.  Came here after Girl Talk played the Fillmore (so I was already in a fantastic mood), had some beer and decompressed with some friends.  Very nice, very chill, I could definitely see myself becoming a regular here.

Next time I'm trying the Soju.  Then maybe, it'll get that elusive 5th star.
author: Erika C.

description: I went there on a  Friday night, so it was a bit crowded but my friend and I were lucky to find a table for two. We tried their different sake cocktails and soju cocktails. The bartender that night made the drinks pretty strong, they tasted like alcohol ( I expected it to be sweeter though). I didn't stay for all night, but I had a good time there
author: Naomi L.

description:
I'm going 4 stars on this little corner bar for a plethora of reasons:  it's within stumbling distance of my house, the bartenders are quick and efficient and don't ignore you, and the bar food is way the hell above average.  The salads are good and they've got damn fine little pizzas.  Their happy hour is noon to 6p on weekdays which will give you $2 off beers and 50% off that damn fine little pizza ($4!!)  That's some smart math there friends.  
I can't knock the crowd here because no one has fought me or thrown up on me and that's my standard- pool table is generally available and far enough out of the way so you don't have to say "mind your nuts" every time you want to make a shot.  All good.  
Oh- and for New Years my friend was able to talk the bartender into serving mixed drinks by the pitcher-  BIG TIMESAVER!

All in all I think the Fly is pretty fly for this white guy.
author: Johnny G.

description:
This is my local bar so I may be biased. I started coming to Fly when I still lived in Berkeley and when I made the move across the Bay, NoPa was one of my top neighborhood choices partly because of the awesome-ness that is Fly. 

Yes, it can get crowded. Yes, it can be filled with scowling trendy hipsters. Yes, the "Mayor" of Divis will probably hit on you.

But it still, hands down, has the best bar food (I highly recommend the pizza or salads - all great options!), yummiest soju cocktails, and nicest bartenders around. Happy hour is great too - $3 drinks and half off pizza! 

This place is always my go-to when I have friends in town or if I need a drink or two after work. I highly recommend it. :)
author: Lauren B.

description:
I haven't been here for years and do remember liking this place. Then the other night I went here on Saturday night and started to remember what  I like about this place.

I normally don't like going out on Saturday nights because places tend to get crazy, crowded, and its when the B&Ts come out (okay, okay, am getting old)... but this place, is definitely a locals place. The people that come here are diverse and just chill people with an edge (far from my Marina home) and the vibe is a very open one. 

The sangria here is yum - one of the things they are known for - and usually my drink of choice here. Great and fun background music where you may leave suddenly feeling like you want to go off and dance. I heard they have good happy hour so I need to try that very soon.

Overall, for a Saturday night, it was perfect.
author: Bernadette L.

description:
If you have not yet hit up this gem, get a grip on your life and do so quickly.  

The quasi-renaissance / bohemian / swanky / divey / sheik - approach had me at hello.  Two pitchers of home-made sangria later and life is good.  Good vibes, cool employees.  I'll be back.
author: S M.

description:
After being disappointed by Bar821, my friends and I decided to come here. 

Me: Can I get a SoCo and Coke? 
Bartender: What? 
Me: SoCo and Coke!
Bartender: Oh, we don't have hard liquor here
Me: Oh....

What a girl gotta do to get drunk?! I'm still amazed with this SF bars phenomenon. You called yourself a bar, but you don't carry liquors. It's like calling yourself a laundromat but all you have is washers. 

Aside from the drinks option, it's a pretty decent place to hang out though the music selection was odd.
author: Perry S.

description:
Although I am definitely not a hipster (mental note: the first sign of being a hipster is denying that you are one), I must admit that I do tend to avoid the kinds of bars that Robert Lanham lists in his priceless expose of hipsteria ("The Hipster'ss Handbook", 2002).  Let me quote the pearls of wisdom that you will find on page 35.

Hipsters despise these kinds of bars:

-Sports Bar (those attended by "jocks who wear numbered jerseys or white baseball caps")

-Bars with Dartboards (because "they tend to attract the same crowds found at sports bars")

- Bars with Blended Drinks (because "these bars draw in boys who like Jimmy Buffett and the type of women one sees on E! channel")

- Cigar Bars (because "they are frequented by creepy CEOs and Wall Street types who shred questionable accounting documents and cheat on their wives with hookers")

- High Profile Bars and Clubs (because "bars with beefy bouncers and stretch limos parked outside are midtown. They attract the fashion-deprived elite and are almost always tourist traps for the hipster wanna-bes, guys with ponytails, and tassels with flubber")

Now, I would add to this list that generic bars with television hanged on the wall - and usually tuned to some sport event - should also be banned for life. Pubs too are evil. too. I mean, they serve beer and greasy fries! How dare they?

And yet, occasionally it's refreshing to see that there's life beyond the wine bar ghetto. Amelie is addictive, but an overdose of Bordeaux is to be avoided. At all costs.

The good news is that among the bars that you'll find on that fascinating street that is Divisadero - so charismatic that celebrated author Michael Ondaatje used for the title of a novel (which I have not read, therefore I am fully entitled to mention and even recommend) - Fly Bar is the king of the hill. 

Yes, there is a television set perpetually tuned to some boring sport event above the entrance (sigh). 

And yes, it features not one, not two, but three pool tables, another cardinal sin because pool tables are magnets that attract "jocks who wear numbered jerseys or white baseball caps".

But still, bear with me.

Fly Bar makes outstanding soujou and sake drinks.

The fact that these drinks are affordable is a bonus, especially in harsh economic times like these when even shopping at entry-level drugstores like Whole Foods can become a nuisance. 

I would recommend Soujou Nectar (soujou and Pineapple Juice). (tip: all considerate men should drink pineapple juice on a date. Trust me on that). 

Fly Bar is conveniently located a block away from club formerly known as Justice League, aka The Independent, making it the perfect spot for a pre-concert  refill. 

Happy hour is every hour. The staff is generally good but changes constantly (quality of service varies from really good to really bad - which makes a visit always exciting - "What's gonna be this time? "Will I fight with the bartender? Will I fall in love with the waitress?" suspense! suspense!).

Hence the four stars.

Without the TV set and the pool tables, I would crank it up to six.
author: Matt B.

description:
Soju and Sake only??

Next time, put that on a neon sign outside and cross out the word BAR.  
Oh, and to the overly informative patron to my right: True, sojo isn't all that bad. Neither are winecoolers, but people don't go a bar for winecoolers, now, do they?
author: Mollie T.

description:
This place is the EPITOME of hit-and-miss. I've been here on crowded, sweaty Friday nights when it's been the last place on Earth I'd rather be, and then I've chilled here for hours on a Tuesday evening when I couldn't be happier, sampling the many beers and enjoying the food.

It's in the heart of the Soju Triangle. Meaning, if you're a guy, hesitate before bringing a date here, because the moment she orders her Greyhound, they're gonna retaliate with the "we don't serve liquor" decree. GRRR... no female, no matter how much she insists, enjoys a soju cocktail. She just doesn't - know this and you'll be all the wiser...

Having said that, a chill evening here on a random weekday is well-advised - get here before 6:30, and enjoy the happy hour in which you can enjoy their quality pizzas at half price. And honestly, after seeing the worst of this place at midnight on a Saturday, the weekday evenings at Fly are super chill, and make you grateful that this bar exists.
author: Drew S.

description:
Pretty much my "Cheers."

It's a decent bar with decent food and nice people both behind and around the bar.  

And its proximity to my house is the real winner.  It's so close it's very very hard for my roomate or I to not be able to talk each other into getting a drink anytime of the week.
author: Matthew R.

description:
LOVE this place!
$5 pizzas during happy hour (6 of the 10 options are veggie, too) which are AWESOME and gourmet, $3 drinks (and they serve PBR!) and friendly and helpful service.
They are exceedingly cool here, and though they may appear to be *hipster* or *too cool for school*, have NEVER given me attitude or left me feeling unwelcome.
It does get crazy crowded on the weekends and at night, so I try to patronize them in the afternoon...
:)
author: D C.

description:
Fly's nothing special, but for a quick drink and a cheap mediocre meal, it does the trick.  It's definitely one of the better spots in the Nopa neighborhood.

Points for the playlist though - Fugazi, Tribe Called Quest, Mos Def, Death Cab, Madonna -- did someone raid my iTunes library???
author: Jenny S.

description:
Good place to go before a show at the Independent. We were going to go to Nopa but of course it was packed so we found ourselves drawn to the Fly. It's in a great spot for pre show beverages and food. I had a pizza and a salad and both were good. If it's crowded, and it will be before a show, it can be a pain in the ass to sit and eat. Anymore that 3 to a table and you are going to have to stack your plates to eat. but then again it's a bar that happens to serve food. 
They were busting some MJ which was kind of fun. Kind of. the only real complaint i have is that it's very small. If you are going to be a restaurant then make it so you can actually sit and eat. if you are going to be a bar, get the damn tables out of the way so you can have some room to get your drink on. But at least they don't have a $30 min on credit cards like the Independent.
author: Stephen K.

description:
My ex used to live off of Divisadero (well, prolly still does but who gives a #$%), so I've passed Fly a number of times over the past 3 years I've lived up here...and never once felt compelled to go inside.

Well - I regret that decision.

I was headed to a show at the Independent this past weekend, and we ended up going to Fly beforehand to meet up with the bassist from the band (why are bassists always so effing hawt?), so he could stay nearby for soundcheck.

The outside of Fly is desceiving (and part of why I never went in).  The windows are dark, the sign looks like it was xeroxed and the paint seems a lil chipped.  Inside, though, the place is dive-y cute.  
Small tables, and a few large booths.  A pool table.  A bar.  And a kitchen hidden somewhere.

We had some beers, one of their soju-cocktails (saki-infused since they can't serve hard liquor) and few pitchers of sangria.  The sangria was delicious, and a half pitcher fills 4 sizeable glasses.  The soju-cocktail was alright - nothing all that exciting.  And I assume the beer was good.  Our server was a sweet lil lass, who was great about being there exactly when we needed her.

We didn't order food, but I saw several plates being delivered and I gotta say - that grub looked GOOD.  I wasn't hungry, but I was seriously considering eating anyway.  Yum-tastic.

After the show at the Independent, we'd had such a good time at Fly, we headed back, and spent a few more hours soaking up the atmosphere and sangria.  Unfortunately, they'd stopped serving food, but our sweet server-type told us we were welcome to bring food in from wherever we wanted (which we did).  There was no line for the pool table (which is always a plus), and we enjoye a riotous, if terribly amateur, game of pool.

So, yeah - good service, yummy looking food, delcious sangria, and a nice, laid-back vibe.  I dig it.  The only downside is the lack of hard liquor, but, uh - that did nothing to deter us from getting far more effed up than we'd intended...
author: Christopher S.

description:
We've stumbled into this place on a number of occasions. 
It's little, it's cute, it serves beer, wine & food.

Typically seating hasn't been an issue so it's a nice place to chat with friends and the open environment lends to making friends with those around you.  (I'm the friendly one!)

Great Art on the walls.  Specifically the mirrored bottle caps hung behind the bar!
author: sUper j.

description: Good atmosphere, great soundtrack, and not too crowded for a Friday night.
author: Elizabeth M.

description:
Amazing happy hour!  For a table of four, we ate and drank for two hours on $54 - a feat unmatched in our other travels in SF.  1/2 price pizzas and $3 drafts is amazing.  We ordered the mushroom pizza, the meat pizza, and the carmel blue.  The carmel blue was tasty, but a few too many caramalized onions for my taste.  The other two pizzas and the fries with malt vinegar aioli were not to miss.  What a lucky find!

The only problem I had with the place was that the bathrooms were dimly-let in red light, so it was a bit treacherous in there after a few of the $3 drafts.
author: Tiffany C.

description:
happy hour pizzas are half off 
and there is a beer plus sake happy hour special. 

we have had a great time here a hand full of times

busy lively spot
tasty food
author: Matthew S.

description:
Sake Bombs? Really? Ok!

For rest of night summary, please refer to Mythic Pizza review...
author: Craig E.

description:
The only time I come to Fly Bar is when I need a place to hang out before the doors at the Independent open.  It's your average not so crowded dive bar that serves super sweet sangrias and has happy hour specials (although I can't remember the exact deal).  All I remember is that if it's cold/rainy/hot and I've got no place to go before a show, I end up here.

On a side note - interesting crowd.
author: Aim E.

description:
Though I liked this place better five years ago when I first moved to the Western Addition, when it was more of a locals hard-drinking beer-bar, and its still that way in the day (they nicely open at 12), but now it's more of a 'dive' for yuppies in the night. I still go here every few weeks for a happy hour pizza and a few beers.

 I've had many many nights here over the years in numerous states of intoxication, used it as a first date spot a couple of times, was politely asked to leave one night and have been graciously allowed back in with no questions asked since. Great bartenders, really above-average barfood, and a good selection of beers. 

Doesn't get five stars for the shitty clientele that crowds it after 7:30 or so. Lot's of Marina folks 'slumming' it in the Western Add. Still, great dark lighting, fairly good Vice-hip indie rock music, one well positioned TV to watch the Giants game, food for pick up. I'll certainly continue to drink and eat here.
author: brant f.

description: Came for drinks which were fabulously cheap and if you come a little early on a Sat you can get a table by the window and people watch. The wait staff was pretty attentive and one person ended up ordering a pizza, which was actually pretty amazing. Great little place, a truly casual but not divey bar.
author: J E.

description:
As one of my local bars, i don't have too many bad things to say about this place.  Its a great bar for when you are sitting at home, want a quick drink and don't want to go very far.  It is only beer, wine,  and soju cocktails, but if you aren't looking for the hard stuff its great.
Nathan works on Sunday nights, and always remembers me when i come in.  I think you can find him most nights at Solstice.
They have a pool table, the Sangria will kick your ass, and the food happy hours are great.  The only difficulty ever is finding a place to sit.
author: Lauren F.

description:
Yet another mediocre, non-booze-serving piece of crap bar in Nopa, or whatever the fuck you wanna call it.  

What is up with this neighborhood?  Why is every place so goddamn run of the mill that you get the feeling that no matter how much you drink, no fun adventures are gonna happen?  Like, you're just going to get annoyed by your friends and end up at work with a hangover?  You're not gonna meet any cute guys, and there will NOT be debauchery.  I guess I'll move to this neighborhood and hang out at these bars after I get my lobotomy and become certifiably lame.
author: Coco D.

description:
I have driven by this spot for years. Too many years. And, more importantly I am VIP across the street at Eddys ( which I highly recommend soaking up unwanted booze a la 11am Sunday morning).  I tried to like it. The waitress was an idiot and believed that living in SF for three years made her a Native, which is beyond hysterical, and I think I made her almost cry by the end of it. 
She forgot all of our food orders and was condesending about it. The sake drinks were, "meh" and I could have done better at a Sizzler salad buffet then the pathetic one they served me. Im leaving this one to the cheeezzzzeee balls who frequent this place all damn day.
author: Liz C.

description: had to kill time since the maid service was at mi casa, and i finally had the HH pizzas, they were so effin dericious! i had the book em danno and MMM..meat pizzas.  see pic.
author: Pickle R.

description:
Fly Bar is everything a bar should be: friendly bartenders, a wide selection of beer, drinkable wine, and a few house specials. 
The first time I went to Fly Bar was on Halloween night. Like most bars, it was crowded and hot, but what set it apart was how friendly both the employees and other customers were. 
I was definitely Justin Bieber for Halloween, and when I accidentally mentioned to the young man behind me in the bathroom line that he also looked like J.Biebz I was greeted with a jovial, "I have no idea who that is, but thank you!" 
Needless to say, I was stoked to be in such pleasant company. 
I would recommend getting insanely happy off Fly Bar's homemade Sangria (served out of a punch bowl). This stuff is GOOD. Have you ever had Sangria that tastes like Hawaiian Punch and nail polish remover? I have. And I've lived with that unfortunate taste for months. 
Luckily, Fly Bar has perfected the art of drinkable Sangria. I don't know what wine they use, but it has an awesomely smooth finish, soft tannins, and a lingering vanilla flavor. Get on that. 
Fly Bar also offers a long list of sake cocktails (including an orange creamsicle option), which I obnoxiously referred to as socktails all night.  And as I said above, their beer selection is also incredible, so take a load off and enjoy your soft stuff. Hard liquor is for alcoholics anyway.
author: Chanti B.

description:
After the Prince vs MJ party after the party is the after party....

And Fly Bar was on the way from the Prince vs MJ party to the car. 

First of all the music was hot! The drinks hmmmm... good who doesn't like Shochu?

And the door guy wasn't bad to look at either LaNon? I think...

The Bartender thought the Girltourage I was with was the entertainment of the night and we were. Laura, a ballet dancer from Oakland was in the building and was feeling herself and the shochu shots....

Rebecca was too cute and there was a man that had to have her fix his necklace *hint hint wink wink

But I had a great time and I am currently making plans to go again... it wasn't too crowdy and the vibe was right!
author: Nicole R.

description:
I'd have to say this is one of my neighborhood go-to spots.  I've had some low-key evenings with friends here as well as some more colorful late nights.  Always seem to have a great time.  Good atmosphere - nothing fancy but not divey either. Not to mention they have one of the best happy hours around.......... 7 days a week 12:00-6:30pm.  

On my list of recommendations is the sangria and "Jimmy the Greek" pizza.
author: Stephani B.

description:
Walked by it the other night and decided to go in. Pretty much your typical SF neighborhood bar with good food and a little class.

It was a little crowded, but at least the patrons seemed to be a good mix of young professionals and not drunken college kids.
author: Cynthia T.

description: Has a nice, cozy feel to it, but there was something wrong with it. First, I tripped over the "handicapped ramp" thing they have right in the entrance. Thanks for putting that warning sign there!!!! It does definitely have a "white bar" feel to it. I like how it's decorated inside and the walls are somewhat brightly colored for a bar. They have a nice looking area in the back with a typical bar box pool table. Bathrooms were nice and clean with paintings inside them. The only complaint I have is that they didn't serve any hard liquor. I was disappointed to say the least.
author: Gerard Y.

description:
The place is pretty cool with some unique but actually frightening art. One thing I was not aware of is that this place does NOT serve hard alcohol, which is not a huge deal, but I did not realize that until I got there. 

The beer list is pretty good and cheap. Beers are either $4 or $5. I didn't have any of their Soju drinks, but the people I was with seemed to enjoy them. 

Bottom Line: The place is pretty cool, but I probably wouldn't go back because I definitely like having the option of getting a mixed drink if the mood strikes.
author: Matthew F.

description:
Good environment.  Love the post modern paintings and the lights hanging from the ceiling.  Cool stars :)

The food was great!  And I love Nigori...yum!  We had the BBQ Chicken pizza, shroom pizza, and the italian salad.  Creative and delicious mixed drinks as well.

Service was fantastic.
author: Andrew S.

description:
Best part of the night... the bar rick-rolled us. Yes, no joke folks, they were blasting Rick Astley loud and proud. 

Pretty good bar, although they don't have a bar license to expect soju cocktails. That being said - the food was excellent! I had this tasty pizza with salad on top... the salad makes the pizza look healthy.

Pool table in the back, nice bartender (I left my ticket at the bar, and he held it for me for an hour until I had realized what I had done), kinda crazy paintings on the wall and a pretty chill crowd.
author: amy b.

description:
I just don't get it, am I supposed to be cool to be in this bar?

I went to this bar, basically because my friend lives by it.  The music was stupid and the crowd didn't mingle, not dance, nor talk to each other.  We all just sat in our seperate worlds at seperate tables and yelled at each other.  Yelling is relative, it was just loud, I wasn't mad at anyone...well, not really...except the stupid crowd.  Maybe I am spoiled because in New Orleans when you go into a bar like The Fly that seems like it should be a neighborhood bar, IT IS a freaking neighborhood bar that is not playing sickeningly repetitive 80's music.

Maybe I just don't like Sangria, or maybe this was the worst Sangria I have ever had, but regardless it was gross, like Kool-aid had been mixed into the wine.  It also has left a lasting impression on my head today.  Ick.
author: Dana M.

description:
Came here last night on a first date. Was thinking of taking her to Madrone, but as she wanted to chill out I chose this spot.

Fly has the easy feel of a neighborhood hangout. The bouncer greeted us warmly. The ambience is vaguely upscale, appropriate for NOPA, but before anyone cries "Begone yuppies!" know that there is a pool table in the back. The place was cracking at midnight on a Saturday night. We grabbed the last free table--near the window, directly under a loudspeaker. The hip-hop soundtrack made conversation challenging, but on the other hand I was glad to learn the source of the sample on Massive Attack's "Five Man Army" ("I'm Glad You're Mine" by Al Green, if you're keeping score). 

Drinks are priced reasonably: $4 for Stella, $4-$5 for the house specialties, soju cocktails. I find the fuss about soju in earlier reviews curious, because you can't taste a hint of the spirit in them. (Maybe that's the issue for those looking to get f'd up.)

In case you're wondering, the date finished well--which I discovered only after the fact. After driving her back to her place and saying good night, I received a text message. "Drive safely. Too bad you didn't make a move when you dropped me off."
author: William L.

description:
Happy hour deliciousness!!

A friend and I popped in for an afternoon drink (we'll call them "business drinks," despite the fact I was unemployed at the time..) and snack. Actually it was the lure of half price happy hour pizzas that made us drop everything we were doing and hop on the 31 asap, and well worth it indeed!

The bartender was nice and efficient, and the clientele seemed like family. The 3 different guys alone at the bar all had girls meet them later, thus making them infinitely less creepy. 2 different men and the bartender offered to help us fix our rickety table.

And the Giants won by a landslide.

Check, check, and CHECK!

I'll be backkkk...
author: Sarah C.

description:
First off, anybody that wrote a 1-star review of this place had something else they must've been cheesed off about when they were there, because there's no way in hell this place deserves that rating.

It's had its ups & downs over the years, sure - for a while I didn't go there much because the clientele seemed to all be under 25, white, and suburbanites-turned-SF'ers. Lately though it's back to the usual neighborhood eclecticism; you'll see a few older folks, a bunch of 30 or 40 somethings, some younguns (mostly well behaved.)

Things I like about Fly:

~  1/2 price pizzas for happy hour? Get outta here! (No, really - it's true!)
~ very friendly & professional servers/bartenders for the most part
~ not a hipster joint
~ mostly family-friendly - meaning you can have some food & beers with your kids in tow and not feel like a bad parent.


Things I'd like to see change:

~ enforcement of the "no smoking within two feet of the door" rule
~ happy hour extended a half hour to an hour
~ stop showing sports on the TV; the only people that watch are loud local drunkards who then let the game's outcome turn them into either manic assholes or depressed assholes

All in all, if you're not an effete trendoid that needs retarded house music or hard liquor to have a good time, this is a great spot. If you ARE this person, there's a place for you just South a few blocks on Divis.
author: Ronzlo L.

description:
Came here on Thursday night.  I had eaten dinner just before arriving, but the pizzas looked pretty damn good.  Nice decor/lighting which made it a chill atmosphere, everyone was able to find a seat.  Wasn't too packed, very mellow crowd, not too loud, GREAT music.  The waitress had some some sick looking tattooes on her shoulders, reaching down her arms (which I find kinda hot).  

Only bad thing was only one bathroom (though it was nice once I got in there to have the whole thing to myself)...I guess it's perfect if you need privacy while doing your recreational drug of choice, but that would be a huge issue on a friday/saturday night for those who have already broken the seal. 

Need to experience this place on a weekend.
author: I AM SOFA KING WE TODD DI D.

description:
I am forced to change my review- while I still live absurdly close to this bar, I no longer frequent it. A change of management, a complete revamping of the beer selection and a significant increase in prices (not to mention run-ins with a surly waitress or two) has turned my affection into something more like revulsion. 

The food is still good, and it's probably a good place for a one-off visit, but I don't recommend frequenting this joint. 

Previous review:------------------
I love this place. It's my second home! Great food, good company - I only wish it didn't get so crowded with 'outsiders' on Friday and Saturdays! Being a neighborhood regular has its perks - but I felt like a regular on my first visit!
author: teriaki b.

description:
The food and Sangria are good.  Happy Hour pizza special is excellent.  They take credit cards.  The girl cocktail servers are pretty cool and always nice when we get there--my friends are the dog's bollocks and know everyone in town, so I'm sure that helps!  Good times. 

Dock one star for no hard stuff and the bartender that was obnoxious (yeah, I'm talking about you, Russ!) and gave us another pitcher when we asked for just one more glass of sangria, joking, "Well, you are getting another pitcher anyway!".  Would've been a great comp EXCEPT that he charged us for it!  Doh! Nice one, big guy.

Bonus points if you happen to catch the Mayor.
author: MakeUp M.

description:
So fly! One of my favorite bars in Western Addition/NOPA. So chill with great bartenders, wait staff and FOOD. Awesome happy hour specials that go all week long 330-630pm - $5 pizzas and $3 draft beers!!

What surprised me the most were how many different types of soju and sake cocktails they had on the menu. Oh and they only serve that, wine, sangria and beer. No hard liquor.

Crowd is laid back and unpretentious. They also have a pool table in the back if you like that kind of thing.
author: Yee-Shing W.

description:
"Love Means Never Having to Say I'm Sorry I killed You" This was the title of the painting on the wall behind us.  I loved the title of the painting (which was a painting of a half naked female from the back hugging a skeleton) 

Came here for happy hour with coworkers and friends.  Love the atmosphere, the people, food, drinks and the service.

I like how it's not like happy hour in the financial district where everyone is dressed in their suits, shirts and ties.  It's a very casual place with a mixed crowd of people.

They have a full bar, with beautiful artwork on the walls and a pool table in the back.  

During happy hour Pizza's are only $5 and Beers are $2( I believe).
I had a Sake Cocktail the JAPANESE CHIWAWA made with sake, red sangria, orange and pineapple juice...it was SOOOOO GOOOD!! Recommended by our server and I loved it.

Pizza's were delicious!!

This is definitely a spot to go to after work to grab a drink or two...a long with some yummy snacks!
author: Sarah F.

description:
I haven't tried the food yet, so this is a partial review.  This is a beer and soju bar, so no liquor for those highball drinkers out there.  Although there is a good selection of beer.  

I found the place inviting, and the people friendly.  I would definitely go back.  Another plus is that it is close to the Independent, so it is my first choice for pre-drinking before a show there.
author: Akshay S.

description:
I went here before a show over at the Independent and got some food and stuff before the show...

No whiskey? Sake Cocktails? Interesting....but not really my thing...so, had to stick to beer...no Newcastle! Bummer. But, it's ok. 

Food, was excellent! I really, really, liked my pizza. It was excellent. 

Service-Not the best I ever had, I don't like having to stare down a waitress to get some service. And it wasn't even that busy at the time, she was just standing over by the bar talking to the other waitress. Damnit! I'm hungry and have a show to go to! Let's get some hustle on this shit! 

Ambiance- was ok I suppose, some of the other people hanging out there were questionable...but hey, who am I to cast the first stone and shit. Overall, I think I'd go back to that Ethiopian place before a show at the independent...
author: Matthew S.

description: Perhaps our bartender was stoned, but she forgot to pour our drinks after ordering them twice.  When she finally remembered, the beers were great.
author: Tyler G.

description:
They have a great happy hour and the Sangria is pretty damn tasty. I live close so I come here on low key nights. I really like the bartenders. They are always super nice and laid back. It is always a fun crowd- not to many drunken fools.

Food is Ehhhh. Pretty typical bar food. Nothing to love but nothing to hate. After a few glasses of wine it def tastes better.
author: Nina Q.

description:
This was the first time I ever tried a sake cocktail and I was very impressed!!  Not only did it taste awesome, but it got me just as tipsy as a regular cocktail.  Two thumbs up!

My pizza was really really good, and I believe I shared an appetizer as well, which was very tasty... I'll have to go back and try more stuff on the menu.  This bar get extra points because it's so original and fun.  I would give it 5 stars except the area felt a little shady to me.
author: Laura W.

description:
A couple friends and I went here for a last drink of a very inebriated night after discovering that the Page down the street was packed.  While my friends ordered manly beers, I decided to order the girliest drink on the menu.  I don't remember what it was, just that it came in a martini glass and had sake in and was fairly tasty.

What I remember through my haze was the ceiling and all the stars -- very entertaining to my not-only-drunk-but-also-stoned mind.  The crowd seemed douchebag-free, and generally well behaved.  -2 stars for not serving hard alcohol (something due to zoning, I think).  Despite that, I'd love to have this bar 2 blocks from my house.

Speaking of 2 blocks -- my friend does live 2 blocks away, and even though he swears he's rarely in there, the bartender had a Guinness poured and ready for him in the time it took him to walk from the front door to the bar.  +1 star for that.
author: Eugene F.

description:
I love Fly Bar!  Every time I go here it is a great experience.  I love the beer selection and the Soju mixed ginger drink.  The drinks are reasonably priced, the bartenders are always friendly and attentive.  I almost always get a spot at the bar or a table... even on weekend nights.

They showcase local artists on the walls, always seem to be playing the right music to fit the mood, and have a very cozy interior.  I'm a sucker for red walls and star lights.  Brings me back to that college dorm room feeling.

Fly Bar is great for a chill night to be comfy and catch up with friends.  Haven't had the food yet but will check it out for happy hour one of these days.
author: Zoe H.

description: $5 sake cocktails! And delicious ones! Nice vibe. Pool table = sweet. Bartender John is awesome. Good fun music.
author: Brinda G.

description: Great happy hour, Yummy tuna melt.
author: Holly H.

description:
